content.div:
LOS ANGELES - As the six-foot-four Liam Neeson takes his seat in a Beverly Hills hotel room, he grimaces a little when greeted with the first question: How are you going to celebrate your 60th birthday?

"I'm not going to celebrate it," he said quickly, referring to the June 7 date. "What am I going to do, go to a strip club? I can't do it, I'm a single parent. But my sons (Michael and Daniel) were saying the other day, 'Well, dad, we have to have a big party for you on your sixtieth.' I said, 'No, we're not.'"

But career-wise, Neeson has lots to celebrate. Not only is he aging well, the Irishman has redefined his career as an action star, after Taken became a worldwide 2008 box-office smash. Last year's Unknown, in which he starred, did decent business as well, and now he's in the middle of preparing for a Taken sequel.

In the meantime, he has reconnected with his A-Team director, Joe Carnahan, to star in the survival thriller, The Grey, which opens across Canada on Jan. 27.

Filmed on location just outside Smithers, B.C., the movie chronicles the attempts of an Alaskan oil-drilling team to survive after a plane crash strands them in the isolated interior of a mountain range. Lack of shelter isn't their only concern, as a menacing pack of wolves starts to hunt the intruders.

Besides Neeson, the film features Dermot Mulroney, Frank Grillo, and James Badge Dale.

Initially, Christian Bale and Bradley Cooper had been considered for the lead, but Carnahan said that, when Neeson took on the main role, The Grey became more telling in its portrayal of grief.

That's because Neeson was married to actress Natasha Richardson, who died in March of 2009, when she suffered severe head trauma in a skiing accident at Quebec's Mont Tremblant resort. Even Neeson quietly acknowledged that The Grey story resonated with him.

"I love that expression, 'How do you make God laugh? You tell him your plans,'" said Neeson. "The older you get, the more you question things. I certainly do. I guess this film echoed that in me very profoundly."

He also enjoyed the adventure, the action and the rawness of filming in the B.C. wilderness near an abandoned snowboarding hill.

"There's something very pure about The Grey, and that's also what attracted me," Neeson said. "There are so many movies nowadays where you see people pressing buttons or expressing a story through an iPhone. This was like a throwback to those old movies that they used make, where it was man versus nature."

The cast had to suffer frigid temperatures and freezing winds, however. "Vanity was left at the Vancouver airport," said Mulroney. "But Liam was our leader."

Neeson insisted he felt more like a follower, who formed strong bonds with the actors determined to get through the sometimes gruelling 14-hour days.

"I loved the enrichment of being with the guys, who are these wonderful actors," said Neeson. "I've made 55 films now, and I think this really is the first time I've been with a group of guys that I still miss to this day."

Did he learn anything else from shooting The Grey? "Never go near snow again," he said, smiling.

Applying that to his Taken 2 deal might be a good idea. But the fact is, he's still amazed by the offers to headline action flicks, thanks to the first Taken.

"Seriously, I find it unbelievably flattering," he said. "Since the Taken movie came out, they're throwing these thriller-assassin movies at me."

And yes, he confirmed, Taken 2 is in the works, but he was skeptical, at first.

"Luc Besson wants to do a Taken 2, but at first, I was like, 'You've got to be crazy. What would it be, She's Taken Again? or Taken For a Ride?' It's like, 'Come on.'"

"(In the end), they came up with an interesting storyline for Taken 2, and I thought, 'OK, lets see what screenplay you come up with here.'"

As he approaches 60, his plan is to "go with the flow," including reprising his role of Zeus in the sequel, Wrath of the Titans, set to open March 30.

Still, the clock is ticking in more ways than one.

"Some action roles are good and some aren't so good, but I love it. As long as my knees hold up, I will give action movies about another 18 months, and that will be it.

"Otherwise," Neeson added with a knowing sigh, "it just gets silly."

The Grey opens Jan. 27.
